moreAbout.paragraph1: GOV.UK accounts are new. At the moment you can only use your GOV.UK account with a few services.
moreAbout.paragraph2: GOV.UK accounts are currently separate from other government accounts (for example Government Gateway or Universal Credit).
moreAbout.paragraph3: In the future, you’ll be able to use your GOV.UK account to sign in to most services on GOV.UK.

shareInfo.title: Share information from your GOV.UK account
shareInfo.header: Share information from your GOV.UK account
shareInfo.bulletPointSectionHeader: This service needs to use your:
shareInfo.paragraph1: You added this information to your GOV.UK account when you created the account. You can choose to share it with the service instead of entering it again when you use the service.
shareInfo.paragraph2: The service will only use this information to contact you about the service. It won’t share your information with anyone else. It will keep your information for as long as it needs to or the law requires it to.
shareInfo.paragraph3: If you choose not to share information from your GOV.UK account, you may still be asked for that information as you use the service. For example if you choose not to share your email address and phone number and the service needs a way to contact you.
shareInfo.essentialHeader: Do you want to share information from your GOV.UK account?

radioText.doNotAgree: Do not share my email address and phone number

info.paragraph1: This cookies policy only covers GOV.UK accounts. Read the main
info.paragraph2: to find out about cookies that are used on GOV.UK.
info.paragraph3: Cookies are files saved on to your phone, tablet or computer when you visit a website. We use cookies to make the GOV.UK account work.
info.paragraph4: We may also use analytics cookies to learn about how you use the account and help us improve it. We'll ask for your permission before we do this.
info.paragraph5: Cookies are not used to identify you personally.
info.paragraph7: on the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) website.

info.bulletPoint3: detect fraudulent or malicious activity and breaches of our terms and conditions

settingsCookies.paragraph1: These cookies do things like remember your preferences and the choices you make, to personalise your experience of using your GOV.UK account.
settingsCookies.paragraph2: We set a cookie when you use your GOV.UK account to save your language preference. At the moment, this defaults to English.

successBanner.linkText: Go back to the page you were looking at

content.paragraph1: GOV.UK accounts are part of the wider GOV.UK website. There’s a separate
content.linkText: accessibility statement for the main GOV.UK website
content.paragraph2: This page only contains information about GOV.UK accounts, available at www.signin.account.gov.uk.

paragraph1.text1: GOV.UK accounts are run by the
paragraph1.text2: , part of the Cabinet Office. We want as many people as possible to be able to use GOV.UK accounts. This means you should be able to:

section1.bulletPoint1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
section1.bulletPoint2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
section1.bulletPoint3: navigate most of the account using just a keyboard
section1.bulletPoint4: navigate most of the account using speech recognition software
section1.bulletPoint5: listen to most of the account content using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
section1.paragraph2: We’ve also made the text in the account as simple as possible to understand.
section1.paragraph3: has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

section2.paragraph1: The following parts of GOV.UK accounts are not fully accessible:
section2.bulletPoint1: it’s not possible to stop or change the length of the time-out when you use, sign in to or create an account
section2.bulletPoint2: one link has poor colour contrast
section2.paragraph2: We’ll update this page when issues are fixed or with information about when we plan to fix them.

section3.header: What to do if you have difficulty using GOV.UK accounts
section3.paragraph1: If you have difficulty using GOV.UK accounts,

section4.header: Report accessibility problems with GOV.UK accounts
section4.paragraph1: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of GOV.UK accounts. If you find any problems not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements,

section5.paragraph1: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’).
section5.paragraph2: If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,
section5.linkText: contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS)

section6.header: Technical information about GOV.UK accounts’ accessibility
section6.paragraph1: The Government Digital Service is committed to making GOV.UK accounts accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.

paragraph2.text1: GOV.UK accounts are partially compliant with the
paragraph2.text2: AA standard, due to the non-compliances listed below.

section7.paragraph1: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
section7.subHeader: Non compliance with the accessibility regulations
section7.paragraph2: When you create an account or sign in, if you do not do anything for 2 hours, the process will stop (time out) or you’ll be signed out. It’s not possible to adjust, extend or turn off the time out. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.2.1 (Timing Adjustable).

section8.header: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
section8.paragraph1: We’ll update this page when issues are fixed, when we expect them to be fixed or when new problems are identified.

section9.paragraph1: This statement was prepared on 4 November 2020. It was last reviewed on 29 June 2022.
section9.paragraph2: GOV.UK accounts were last tested on 13 June 2022. The test was carried out by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC), who produced an accessibility audit report on 17 June 2022. DAC assessed GOV.UK accounts against the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines WCAG 2.1.

paragraph1.text1: These terms and conditions specifically cover GOV.UK accounts. You can use a GOV.UK account to access and use some government services and features. Pages that are part of the GOV.UK account have urls containing account.gov.uk. If you are using other parts of GOV.UK you should also read the

paragraph2.text1: The GOV.UK account is managed by
paragraph2.text2: (GDS) on behalf of the Crown. GDS is part of the Cabinet Office and will be referred to as ‘we’ from now on.

paragraph3.text1: Please read these terms and conditions, the
paragraph3.text3: before using the GOV.UK account. The privacy notice explains the terms on which we process any personal data we collect from you or that you provide to us. The cookie policy gives information about the cookies we use and how we use them when you use GOV.UK or your GOV.UK account.

section1.paragraph4: By registering for and continuing to use a GOV.UK account, you agree to these terms and conditions, the privacy notice and cookies policy.
section1.subHeader: Changes to these terms and conditions
section1.paragraph5: We can update these terms, as well as the cookies policy and privacy notice, at any time without notice.
section1.paragraph6: If we change the terms and conditions, we’ll ask you to accept them the next time you sign in to your account.

section2.paragraph1:
You are responsible for making all arrangements for you to access your GOV.UK account. This includes providing your own device, operating system, browser and internet connection. 
You should use a device that uses a Windows, OS, iOS or Android operating system. We recommend you use one of the following browsers:
section2.bulletPoint1: The latest version of Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Mozilla Firefox, Samsung Internet or Internet Explorer
section2.paragraph2: We do not guarantee that your GOV.UK account will always be available, or that access to it will be error free. We will provide a way for you to report problems with your account.
section2.paragraph3: We may suspend, stop, remove, update or change the GOV.UK account without notice at any time.

paragraph1.text1: We have many measures in place to keep your information safe, but as the owner of your GOV.UK account, you also have some responsibility for the security of your account. For example you should choose a strong password for your account and ensure you keep it secure. The UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) provides
paragraph1.linkText: advice on keeping your online accounts secure

section3.paragraph2: If you think that someone knows the username and password to your GOV.UK account, you must reset your password as soon as possible.

section4.paragraph1: You will use your account to access government services and for no other purpose.
section4.paragraph2: Unless permitted by law or under these terms and conditions, you must:
section4.bulletPoint1: not copy the GOV.UK account except where copying is incidental to normal use
section4.bulletPoint2: not rent, lease, sub-license, loan, translate, merge, adapt, vary or modify the GOV.UK account
section4.bulletPoint3: not combine or incorporate the GOV.UK account with any other programs or services
section4.bulletPoint4: not disassemble, decompile, reverse-engineer or create derivative works based on any part of the GOV.UK account
section4.bulletPoint5: comply with all technology control or export laws that apply to the technology used by the GOV.UK account
section4.paragraph3: You must not use your GOV.UK account:
section4.bulletPoint6: to transmit any material that is insulting or offensive
section4.bulletPoint7: to collect any data or attempt to decipher any transmissions to or from the servers running GOV.UK account
section4.bulletPoint8: in a way that could damage, disable, overburden, impair or compromise our systems or security
section4.bulletPoint9: in a way that interferes with other users
section4.bulletPoint10: in any unlawful or fraudulent manner or for any unlawful or fraudulent purpose
section4.bulletPoint11: in a manner that is improper use or inconsistent with these terms and conditions
section4.bulletPoint12: to gain or attempt to gain unauthorised access to the GOV.UK platform, the server on which the GOV.UK platform is stored or any server, computer or database connected to GOV.UK platform, by hacking or other means
section4.bulletPoint13: to transmit, send or upload any data that contains viruses, Trojan horses, worms, spyware or any other harmful programs designed to adversely affect the operation of computer software or hardware
section4.bulletPoint14: in connection with any kind of denial of service attack or for any malicious purpose
section4.bulletPoint15: with someone else’s registered details , unless you have the authority to do so from them
section4.paragraph4: If you breach any of these terms and conditions, we may stop you from accessing your GOV.UK account and may take action to enforce these terms and conditions and take other action as appropriate where we have suffered loss. If, by doing any of the above acts, you are also committing a criminal offence, we may report it to the relevant law enforcement authorities. We may cooperate with those authorities by disclosing your identity to them.

paragraph1.text1: You can permanently delete your account and the information in it at any time by signing in to your account or
paragraph1.text2: We'll keep a record of certain information, in line with our
paragraph1.text3: , for audit purposes and to help prevent crime.

section6.paragraph1: We can make changes and improvements to the GOV.UK account at any time and without notice to:
section6.bulletPoint2: improve the performance of the service
section6.bulletPoint4: reflect changes to the operating system

section7.paragraph1: You can use your GOV.UK account to access online government services. These services can be managed by GDS, the Cabinet Office or another government department or agency.
section7.paragraph2: Each service will have their own, separate terms and conditions, privacy notices and cookies policies, which apply to the use of that service. You should read these before you use the service.
section7.paragraph3: If a service run by another government department or agency stops being accessible with GOV.UK accounts the service will contact you to tell you what you should do.

section8.paragraph1: The GOV.UK account is a tool and we have no liability to you for the online government services that you access using the GOV.UK account. Liability to you rests with the government service provider.
section8.paragraph2: Although we make reasonable efforts to provide, maintain and update a robust GOV.UK account service, it is provided 'as is'. We make no express or implied representations, warranties or guarantees that your access to, or use of, GOV.UK account will be unbroken or completely secure.
section8.paragraph3: We will not be liable or responsible for any loss or damage caused by a virus, denial of service attack or any other harmful material that may infect your device, equipment, programs, data or other proprietary material due to your use of a GOV.UK account.
section8.paragraph4: Nothing in these terms and conditions excludes or limits our liability for:
section8.bulletPoint1: death or personal injury as a result of our negligence
section8.bulletPoint3: any other liability which cannot be excluded or limited under English law
section8.bulletPoint4: loss or damage that may come from using the GOV.UK account that is not caused by our breach of these terms and conditions
section8.bulletPoint5: loss or damage to a device or digital content belonging to you
section8.bulletPoint6: loss or damage arising from an inability to access or use your GOV.UK account
section8.bulletPoint7: indirect or subsequent losses that were not foreseeable to both you and us when you started using your GOV.UK account (loss or damages are ‘foreseeable’ when they are an obvious result of our breach of these terms and conditions or if they were considered by you and us when you began using the GOV.UK account)
section8.bulletPoint8: loss of profits, revenue, contracts, savings, goodwill and wasted expenditure
section8.paragraph6: GDS is not liable for its failure to comply with the terms and conditions due to circumstances which are beyond GDS’ control.
section8.paragraph7: This does not affect any legal rights you may have as a consumer in relation to faulty services or software. Advice about your legal rights is available from your local Citizen’s Advice or Trading Standards Office.
section8.paragraph8: We are not responsible for any links from your GOV.UK account links to websites that are managed by other government departments and agencies, service providers or other organisations. We do not have any control over the content on these websites.
section8.bulletPoint9: the protection of any information you give to these websites
section8.bulletPoint10: any loss or damage that may come from your use of these websites, or any other websites they link to
section8.paragraph10: You agree to release us from any claims or disputes that may come from using these websites.
section8.paragraph11: You should read all terms and conditions, privacy policies and end user licences that relate to these websites before you use them.

section9.header: Making sure these terms and conditions are followed
section9.paragraph1: Each section within these terms and conditions operates separately. If any provision in these terms and conditions is invalid or unenforceable according to applicable law, we will replace it with a valid and enforceable provision that most closely matches the intent of the original. This includes warranty disclaimers and exclusions, and limits of liability. The rest of these terms and conditions will remain in effect.
section9.paragraph2: If we delay in enforcing these terms and conditions, we can still enforce them later. If we do not insist right away that you follow the requirements within these terms and conditions, or we delay in taking steps against you if you break them, this will not prevent us from taking steps against you or prevent your need to follow the requirements at a later date.

section10.paragraph1: The laws of England apply exclusively to these terms and conditions and to all matters relating to use of GOV.UK accounts. Any cause of action arising under or in connection with these terms and conditions or your use of GOV.UK accounts will be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of England.

section11.bulletPoint1: questions about these terms and conditions
section11.bulletPoint2: questions or a complaint about the GOV.UK account

paragraph1.text1: GOV.UK accounts are provided by the
paragraph1.text2: , part of the Cabinet Office. Mentions of ‘us’ and ‘we’ in this privacy notice refer to GDS.

paragraph2.text1: This privacy notice only covers GOV.UK accounts. Read the main
paragraph2.text2: to find out how your personal information is collected and processed when you use the GOV.UK website.

section1.paragraph3: The Cabinet Office is the data controller of the personal information you provide to us when you:
section1.bulletPoint2: use your GOV.UK account to access an online government service
section1.paragraph4: When you provide information to another government service while signed into your account, the government department that runs the service is the data controller. They will have their own privacy notice to explain how they process your information. We do not have access to the information you provide to services run by other government departments.
section1.paragraph5: When you prove your identity with a GOV.UK account, we will:
section1.bulletPoint4: ask you for your passport details - we'll check these with HM Passport Office (HMPO)

bulletPoint5.text4: to make sure you've not been a victim of identity theft

section1.bulletPoint6: use Experian's data to ask you security questions that only you should know the answers to - Experian will also check that your answers match the information they already have about you
section1.paragraph6: HMPO and Experian will also become data controllers during this process. We do not keep any information you give us when proving your identity, including your answers to the security questions.

section2.paragraph1: When you use a service that requires a GOV.UK account, we’ll receive information about the service when it directs you to:
section2.bulletPoint1: create or sign in to an account
section2.paragraph2: The information we collect when you create and use a GOV.UK account includes:
section2.bulletPoint3: basic personal information needed to set up and authenticate your account, including your email address and mobile phone number
section2.bulletPoint4: other information needed to prove your identity, such as your name, date of birth, passport details and address history
section2.bulletPoint5: any information that you choose to save to your account, for example your GOV.UK email subscription preferences

bulletPoint6.text1: information on how you use your account and the GOV.UK website, which is collected in the system logs, and by Google Analytics cookies if you give consent - the

section2.bulletPoint7: online identifiers, such as your Internet Protocol (IP) address, and technical information about the device you use including the model, web browser and operating system, which is automatically collected in system logs when you use GOV.UK
section2.bulletPoint8: questions, queries or feedback you leave, including your name and email address, if you provide them on the GOV.UK accounts contact form
section2.bulletPoint9: if you were able to prove your identity with your GOV.UK account
section2.bulletPoint10: what organisations, services or information we used to prove your identity
section2.paragraph3: When you create an account, it will automatically generate a unique account identifier.

section3.paragraph1: We collect your personal information to:
section3.bulletPoint1: provide you with a GOV.UK account so that you can use it to access online government services

bulletPoint3.text1: store your preferences, for example your

section3.paragraph2: We also use your information to:
section3.bulletPoint4: keep your account secure (using your email address, phone number, password and system logs)
section3.bulletPoint6: tell the services you access through your GOV.UK account that you have successfully signed in
section3.bulletPoint7: provide government services that you access through your account and the departments that run them with information you explicitly agree to us sharing, for example your email and telephone number
section3.bulletPoint8: provide you with a record of how your account has been used, for example, when it was last signed in to and what services it has been used with
section3.bulletPoint9: contact you about any planned interruptions, problems or changes that may affect your account (using your email address)
section3.bulletPoint10: contact you to ask for feedback on your account, if you have given us permission to (using your email address)

bulletPoint11.text3: improve and understand how you use your GOV.UK account
bulletPoint11.text4: (you can choose not to accept these cookies)

section3.bulletPoint12: respond to any feedback you send us, if you’ve asked us to
section3.paragraph3: We may also use your information to produce anonymised reports about GOV.UK accounts. This helps us understand where we can make improvements to GOV.UK accounts.

section4.header: Our legal basis for processing your information
section4.paragraph1: When we process information for security and fraud monitoring, the legal basis is our legitimate interests.
section4.paragraph2: When we process information to make improvements to GOV.UK accounts, the legal basis is your explicit consent. This includes:
section4.bulletPoint1: collecting and analysing information about how you use your GOV.UK account using Google Analytics cookies
section4.bulletPoint2: emailing you to ask for feedback about your account
section4.paragraph3: The legal basis for processing all other personal data is that it’s necessary in the exercise of our functions as a government department.

section5.header: Who we share your information with
section5.bulletPoint1: sell or rent your information to third parties
section5.bulletPoint2: share your information with third parties for marketing purposes
section5.subHeader1: Sharing your information with online government services and the departments that run them
section5.paragraph2: We'll tell the services that you access through your account when you successfully create your account or sign in so that they can allow you to use the service.
section5.paragraph3: Services you access through your account may ask you to share information you have saved in your GOV.UK account. When they do this, we'll tell you which information they have asked for, and will only share the information if you agree.
section5.paragraph4: If you do not choose to share this information from your GOV.UK account, you might be asked to provide the same information directly to the service later on.
section5.paragraph5: Each service you access through your GOV.UK account will have its own terms and conditions and privacy notice. You should read these as well as the GOV.UK accounts terms and conditions and this privacy notice, so that you understand how your personal information is managed.
section5.subHeader2: Sharing your information to prove your identity
section5.paragraph6: We'll share your information with HMPO and Experian when we prove your identity. We'll only give them the information they need to do this check. They will keep your details for as long as they need to or the law requires them to do so.
section5.subHeader3: Sharing your information to protect against fraud
section5.paragraph7: To protect against crime and fraud, we might sometimes share information with:
section5.bulletPoint3: government departments that run the services you access though your account
section5.bulletPoint4: other public sector organisations, such as the Home Office
section5.bulletPoint7: data processors who provide relevant monitoring services
section5.paragraph8: The information we might share includes:
section5.bulletPoint12: information about the devices being used
section5.bulletPoint13: passport details, including name and date of birth
section5.subHeader4: Sharing your information with our suppliers
section5.paragraph9: We work with technology suppliers, for example we use an external hosting provider. These suppliers may have access to your information as part of providing their services to us.

section6.header: How long we keep your information
section6.paragraph1: We store your personal information for as long as is reasonably necessary and legally justifiable.
section6.paragraph2: We will keep your account and any information saved in it for as long as you use it. If you delete your account or if you don’t sign in for 2 years, we’ll delete all the information associated with it. Any information you delete from your account will be permanently deleted.
section6.paragraph3: We will keep your feedback data for 2 years.
section6.paragraph4: We will delete access log data after 365 days.
section6.paragraph5: We will store information about the actions you take and how you use the account for 7 years, for fraud monitoring purposes.

section7.paragraph1: GOV.UK accounts are not designed for, or intentionally targeted at, children 13 years of age or younger. We do not intentionally collect or maintain information about anyone under the age of 13.

section8.header: Where your information is processed and stored
section8.paragraph1: All personal data and information associated with your GOV.UK account is stored in the UK or in the European Economic Area (EEA). The EEA has been assessed by the Information Commissioner’s Office as having adequate legal protections for data privacy in line with those in the UK.
section8.paragraph2: Where our suppliers require access to your data, they may do so from outside of the EEA. Data collected by Google Analytics may be transferred outside the European Economic Area (EEA) for processing. When either of these things happen, we will make sure your information is just as well protected, for example by including extra clauses in our contracts with suppliers.

section9.header: How we protect your personal information and keep it secure
section9.paragraph1: We are committed to doing all that we can to keep your information secure. We have set up systems and processes to prevent unauthorised access or disclosure of your information - for example, we use varying levels of encryption. We also make sure that any third parties that we deal with keep all personal information they process on our behalf secure.
section9.paragraph2: As the owner of your GOV.UK account, you also have some responsibility for the security of your account. For example, you should:

bulletPoint1.text1: choose a strong password for your account and ensure you keep it secure - the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) provides
bulletPoint1.linkText: advice on keeping your online accounts secure

section9.bulletPoint2: contact us immediately if you suspect that your account has been compromised

section10.paragraph1: Your personal information will be subject to automated decision making when:
section10.bulletPoint1: your passport details are checked against data held by HMPO
section10.bulletPoint2: Experian runs an identity fraud check to make sure you've not had your identity stolen
section10.bulletPoint3: your answers to security questions are matched against data held by Experian

section11.paragraph1: When you are signed in to your account you can:
section11.bulletPoint1: access all personal information associated with your GOV.UK account
section11.bulletPoint2: change or update your information such as your email address, password and email subscription preferences
section11.bulletPoint3: change your consent to non-essential cookies or tell us how you want us to contact you
section11.bulletPoint4: delete information from your account (apart from your email address, mobile phone number and password because you can’t access your account without them)
section11.bulletPoint6: withdraw your consent for your personal information to be processed using web analytics data or feedback
section11.bulletPoint7: object to how your personal information is processed
section11.bulletPoint8: ask that the processing of your personal information is restricted in certain circumstances
section11.bulletPoint9: contact us to get help if you're not able to prove your identity online

paragraph3.text1: If you have any of these requests, contact the

section12.header: Contact us or make a complaint
section12.paragraph1: Contact the GDS Privacy Team if you:
section12.bulletPoint1: have a question about anything in this privacy notice
section12.bulletPoint2: think that your personal information has been misused or mishandled
section12.bulletPoint3: want to make a 'subject access request' to find out more about how your personal information is collected and used
section12.paragraph2: You can also contact our Data Protection Officer (DPO) who provides independent advice and monitoring of our use of personal information:
section12.paragraph3: You can also make a complaint to the Information Commissioner, who is an independent regulator.
section12.paragraph4: Making a complaint to the Information Commissioner will not affect your rights.

section13.paragraph1: We may change this privacy policy. In that case, the ‘last updated’ date of this document will also change. Any changes to this privacy policy will apply to you and your information immediately.
section13.paragraph2: If these changes affect how your personal information is processed, GDS will let you know.

password.label: Enter a new password
password.paragraph2: Do not use a very common password, such as ‘password’ or a sequence of numbers.

validationError.maxLength: Your password must be less than 256 characters

securePasswordDetails.summary: How to create a secure password
securePasswordDetails.text: A good way to create a secure and memorable password is to use 3 random words. You can use numbers, symbols and spaces.

section1.header: What do you need help with?

supportTypeRadios.govServiceRadioText: I work in a government service team and we want to start using GOV.UK Sign In
supportTypeRadios.publicRadioText: I’m a member of the public
supportTypeRadios.errorMessage: You must select an option to tell us what you need help with

section2.paragraph1: We can only respond to your support queries during office hours. Our office hours are 9:30am to 5:30pm, Monday to Friday.
section2.paragraph2: When you get in touch during office hours, we’ll try to reply within 2 working days.

contactUsGov.title: Contact Us
contactUsGov.paragraph1: You can find out how to:

paragraph2.text: Or if you still have questions, you can contact us at

contactUsPublic.title: Contact us
contactUsPublic.header: GOV.UK account: report a problem or give feedback

section1.bulletPoint1: tell us about a problem you’re having with your GOV.UK account
section1.bulletPoint2: suggest improvements or give feedback about your experience using your GOV.UK account
section1.paragraph2: Our office hours are 9:30am to 5:30pm, Monday to Friday. We'll respond to you by email in 2 working days.

contactUsSubmitSuccess.title: Your message has been submitted
contactUsSubmitSuccess.paragraph2: We'll respond to you in 2 working days.

proveIdentityWelcome.title: Prove your identity with a GOV.UK account
proveIdentityWelcome.header: Prove your identity with a GOV.UK account

section1.paragraph1: You can currently only prove your identity with your GOV.UK account if you have a UK passport.
section1.insetTextPassport: If your passport has expired, you can still use it to prove your identity up until 18 months after the expiry date.

section2.paragraph1: It will take you about 10 minutes to prove your identity this way.
section2.insetTextEnglishOnly: This service is currently only available in English.
section2.paragraph2: You'll need to create or sign in to your GOV.UK account first. We'll then ask you for your current address and passport details.
section2.paragraph3: We'll also ask you some security questions that only you should know the answers to. You might find it easier to answer these questions if you have information about:
section2.listItem3: any credit cards, loans or mortgages you have
section2.paragraph4: We'll only use the information you give us to make sure that you are who you say you are.

section3.subHeading: Choose a way to prove your identity
section3.radioOption1: Continue to sign in or create a GOV.UK account
section3.radioOption1HintText: Make sure you have your UK passport with you before you continue. You might still be able to prove your identity if you do not have your passport but know the details on it.
section3.radioOption2HintText: You can prove your identity online with GOV.UK Verify or take your identity documents to be checked in person.

existingSession.paragraph1: If you don't have a passport,
existingSession.linkText: you can prove your identity another way

getSecurityCodes.title: Choose how to get security codes
getSecurityCodes.header: Choose how to get security codes
getSecurityCodes.summary: To finish creating your account, you need to choose a way to prove it's you when you sign in.
getSecurityCodes.summaryAccountPartCreated: Choose a way to get security codes when you sign in. This helps keep your account secure.

secondFactorRadios.authAppText: Authenticator app for smartphone, tablet or computer
secondFactorRadios.errorMessage: Select how you want to get security codes

authAppDetails.paragraph1: An authenticator app creates a security code that helps confirm it's you when you sign in.
authAppDetails.paragraph2: You can use an authenticator app on your smartphone, tablet or desktop computer.  Download an authenticator app for your smartphone or tablet from your app store or search online for an authenticator app for your computer.

setupAuthenticatorApp.title: Set up an authenticator app
setupAuthenticatorApp.step1: 1. Open your authenticator app on your smartphone, tablet or computer.

noAuthAppDetails.summaryText: I don't have an authenticator app
noAuthAppDetails.paragraph1: You can download an authenticator app for your smartphone or tablet from your app store.
noAuthAppDetails.paragraph2: If you don't have a smartphone or tablet, search online for an authenticator app for your computer.
noAuthAppDetails.paragraph3: You can use any authenticator app.

setupAuthenticatorApp.step2: 2. Use your authenticator app to scan the QR code or type the secret key into your authenticator app.  Some authenticator apps call the secret key a 'code'.
setupAuthenticatorApp.step3: 3. The authenticator app will show an security code.

code.label: Security code
code.hintText: This is the 6-digit number shown in your authenticator app

validationError.required: Enter the security code shown in your authenticator app
validationError.invalidCode: The security code you entered is not correct, try entering it again or wait for for your authenticator app to give you a new code
validationError.length: Enter the security code using only 6 digits

enterAuthenticatorAppCode.title: Enter the 6 digit security code shown in your authenticator app
enterAuthenticatorAppCode.header: Enter the 6 digit security code shown in your authenticator app

validationError.invalidFormat: Enter the security code using only 6 digits
validationError.invalidCode: The security code you entered is not correct, try entering it again or wait for your authenticator app to give you a new code
